DOC.HEAD: Eastern Cuts 600 Jobs, Trims 10,000 Salaries
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines plans 600 more layoffs along with salary cuts for half its employees under measures to stem the flood of red ink that has swamped the airline for a decade. About 10,000 workers will have wages temporarily slashed from 10 percent to 20 percent, although some of those cuts must be negotiated with the Air Line Pilots Association and the flight attendants union. The principal cause of the cuts _ which were announced Thursday _ is the sale of Eastern's Latin American routes to American Airlines. But Tom Matthews, Eastern's senior vice president for human resources, also cited ``the softness in the economy ... the increase in fuel prices, the extensive competition in the Miami hub,'' particularly from Pan American World Airways. The package is expected to save $100 million next year for Eastern, which reported a $185.2 million loss in this year's third quarter. Eastern President Phil Bakes said pay and benefit reductions were ``something we wanted to avoid,'' but that large losses are expected to continue in the first half of the new year. The cuts are also part of Eastern's bankruptcy court plan for financial reorganization that stemmed from the March 4 strike that virtually idled the Miami-based carrier for weeks. Eastern claimed it was losing $1 million a day prior to the strike. The majority of the layoffs will involve administrative and airport service personnel, and will not include the unionized pilots, flight attendants or mechanics. Attrition and early retirement will blunt the effects of the cutbacks, but a number of operations-related employees will be out of work Jan. 31 as Miami operations fall from 75 to 50 daily flights. Job cuts also will come July 1 when American Airlines is scheduled to assume the Latin routes. Meanwhile, half of Eastern's 20,000 employees _ including management, pilots and flight attendants working at the older, higher wage levels _ will have their wages cut by 10 percent to 20 percent for a year, beginning Jan. 16. About 850 pilots will see their $72,000 salaries slashed by 20 percent for six months. Half of the cut will be restored after six months, and wages are scheduled to return to normal after a year. About 950 newly hired pilots are working for $27,500 a year and will not be affected. Flight attendants earning a pre-strike salary of $30,000 a year will take a 15 percent initial cut, but those hired under the new wage levels of $15,000 will not. Machinists, who had cuts imposed when the strike began, aren't affected. Machinists remain the only group that hasn't gone back to work. Mary Jane Barry, head of Eastern's flight attendants union, refused to comment on the proposal, saying negotiations were continuing. Calls to ALPA were not returned. Eastern employed 32,000 before the strike began, and the airline filed for bankruptcy protection five days later. Eastern, a Texas Air Corp. subsidiary, plans to reshape itself with about 75 percent of its operations centered at Atlanta.
